Award.AwardTitle: A Model-based Investigation of Climate Variability and Climate Change: Focus on the West African Monsoon System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will assess climate variability and climate change of the West Africa (WA) summer monsoon, based on the analysis of simulations of Regional Model version #3 (RM3) of the Columbia University Center for Climate Systems Research. The investigators will (i) determine the optimum configuration of the RM3 for simulating projections of WA climate change, (ii) investigate the interannual variability of WA monsoon onset and African easterly wave activity and how they relate to droughts, and (iii) compute trends in WA precipitation, temperature and monsoon onset date. Model climate change projections during the 21st century will be forced by several global climate models, for each of two greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. RM3 climate projections will be analyzed on a 0.44Â° (~50 km) grid over Africa for two 30-year periods, 2011-2040 and 2041-2070 by comparing these results to a parallel simulation for a base period, 1981-2010. Results will be shared in a new international collaboration, a COordinated Regional climate Downscaling Experiment (CORDEX), an initiative of the World Climate Research Project (WCRP) of the United Nations.

This work will provide more credible projections of WA climate trends, given large uncertainties in projecting how water availability in WA will evolve throughout the 21st century by current climate models. It will provide the first continuous multi-year climatologies of RM3 regional model simulations, for the contemporary and future climate. The proposed research on monsoon onset and on the analysis of African easterly waves will advance the development of seasonal forecasting techniques. The participation in WCRP CORDEX will advance the science of analyzing climate change on a regional scale.

From the perspective of broader impacts, this project will contribute to the CORDEX objective of greater interaction and communication between global climate modelers, the downscaling community and end-users, to better support impact/adaptation activities benefiting Africa's vulnerable population. RM3 simulation results archived by CORDEX will provide data for model intercomparison studies. Model development achievements will be shared with the African Center of Meteorological Applications for Development (ACMAD) in Niamey, Niger, and applied to promote ACMAD RM3 weather and climate guidance simulations, which are made available to users throughout Africa.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project investigates the variability of weather and climate over West Africa, a region that includes the Sahel. The research is preliminary to an investigation of decadal climate change during the 21st century. The Sahel is a semi-arid swath between 10-20N whose population relies on agriculture for sustenance. The rain-fed agriculture is nurtured by summer rains during June-September, the monsoon season. The main tool for the research is a computer based 'regional' atmospheric model that simulates weather and climate over a domain stretching from the Indian to the Atlantic Ocean and from South Africa to Europe. Since the model computes over a limited area, it requires a stream of relevant meteorological data along the domain periphery, which is updated 4x per day. These data, called lateral boundary conditions, link the simulations with the evolution of weather features over the remainder of the globe. Sea surface temperatures (SST) are a specified lower boundary condition throughout the simulations. 

 

Intellectual merit: Because of the model's limited area, it can afford to make computations at very closely spaced grid elements, in this case a spacing of 0.44°. Input data for the lateral boundary conditions, on the other hand, is generally configured at a much coarser resolution. The high horizontal resolution of the regional model grid has the potential for more accurate computations of gradients of important meteorological variables than those of a coarser grid global model. Consequently, the regional model is expected to simulate and to represent spatial climate features more realistically than a global model. For example, the summer rainfall maximum over West Africa at about 10N transitions into the rather dry Sahara with extremely sharp precipitation and ground temperature gradients that cannot be realistically represented by grid elements separated by as much as 2° latitude. Moreover, the strength of the south to north temperature gradient influences the formation of an important jet stream and the development of rain-producing storms over the Sahel. Accordingly, these features are better simulated at the higher grid resolution.

 

This project was one of a number at multiple labs to drive a regional atmospheric model with a fairly new data set computed by the European Center for Medium Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) to produce simulations over Africa for the 1990s and 2000s. The data set represents observed weather conditions 4x per day at 37 vertical levels, with a horizontal spacing of 0.75° latitude and longitude. It is known as the 'ERA-Interim reanalysis'. An alternative data set is produced by the US National Center for Environmental Prediction, called the 'NCEP reanalysis 2', at a horizontal grid spacing of 2.5° latitude and longitude. Project research simulated five years of climate over West Africa, driven by each reanalysis in turn, and compared the resulting regional model simulation results to observational evidence. Contrary to expectations, the regional model simulations of the West African summer monsoon evolution driven by the ERA-Interim reanalysis were not unequivocally more realistic than those driven by NCEP data. Results using ERA data produced a more realistic representation of monsoon wind systems, but rather excessive rainfall patterns that obscured the northward migration over West Africa of the seasonal peak rainfall. Results using NCEP data included slightly weakened monsoon circulation, but very realistic patterns of rainfall, especially the timing of the northward migration of peak rainfall.
